update.description:
This is another part of improving command line tools to control aspects of gazebo.

This pull request creates a camera command message, that can move a simulated camera.

A forthcoming pull request will provide a command line tool that uses this capability.
update.title: Add ability to control camera via messages

pull_request.title: Add ability to control camera via messages

pullrequest.title: Add ability to control camera via messages

content.raw: I think having the private implementations outside of the main header file is good, and the private headers should not be installed too because we don't want to expose them to the users.  `Event.hh` was an exception because it's composed of templates which are hard to separate out.
content.html: I think having the private implementations outside of the main header file is good, and the private headers should not be installed too because we don't want to expose them to the users. Event.hh was an exception because it's composed of templates which are hard to separate out.

content.raw: will the new command line tool be called `gz` as opposed to `gzcamera`?
content.html: will the new command line tool be called gz as opposed to gzcamera?

content.raw:
Not sure if users would know what a `short name`  means.
Something like `unscoped`?
content.html: Not sure if users would know what a short name means. Something like unscoped?

pull_request.title: Add ability to control camera via messages

pullrequest.title: Add ability to control camera via messages

content.raw:
I saw that the `follow_model` field is used and tested, but the `name` and `move_to_position` fields are not used or tested. Currently the name is baked into the topic and is unused in the message.

Do we want to require name if we're not using it?

Assuming we implement move_to_position, should it actually be called move_to_pose?
content.html:
I saw that the follow_model field is used and tested, but the name and move_to_position fields are not used or tested. Currently the name is baked into the topic and is unused in the message.

Do we want to require name if we're not using it?

Assuming we implement move_to_position, should it actually be called move_to_pose?

pull_request.title: Add ability to control camera via messages

pullrequest.title: Add ability to control camera via messages

content.raw: Is this line missing a doxygen comment on purpose because it's the private pointer we don't want people to be using?
content.html: Is this line missing a doxygen comment on purpose because it's the private pointer we don't want people to be using?

pull_request.title: Add ability to control camera via messages

pullrequest.title: Add ability to control camera via messages

content.raw: The CameraPrivate.hh approach seems a little bit different from the approach you took with Event.hh, which included all the private implmentations in the main header file. As long as `class CameraPrivate;` is in Camera.hh, then everything is fine, even though CameraPrivate.hh is neither installed nor included from Camera.hh? Just making sure I understand what's going on.
content.html: The CameraPrivate.hh approach seems a little bit different from the approach you took with Event.hh, which included all the private implmentations in the main header file. As long as class CameraPrivate; is in Camera.hh, then everything is fine, even though CameraPrivate.hh is neither installed nor included from Camera.hh? Just making sure I understand what's going on.

content.raw:
The integration test is failing:

```
#!c++

/home/caguero/workspace/gazebo/test/integration/camera_follow.cc:77: Failure
The difference between camera->GetWorldPose().pos.x and 9.9 is 5.2735470771789554, which exceeds 0.1, where
camera->GetWorldPose().pos.x evaluates to 4.6264529228210449,
9.9 evaluates to 9.9000000000000004, and
0.1 evaluates to 0.10000000000000001.
/home/caguero/workspace/gazebo/test/integration/camera_follow.cc:78: Failure
The difference between camera->GetWorldPose().pos.y and 9.9 is 5.2735470771789554, which exceeds 0.1, where
camera->GetWorldPose().pos.y evaluates to 4.6264529228210449,
9.9 evaluates to 9.9000000000000004, and
0.1 evaluates to 0.10000000000000001.
[  FAILED  ] CameraFollow.Follow (2362 ms)
[----------] 1 test from CameraFollow (2362 ms total)

[----------] Global test environment tear-down
[==========] 1 test from 1 test case ran. (2362 ms total)
[  PASSED  ] 0 tests.
[  FAILED  ] 1 test, listed below:
[  FAILED  ] CameraFollow.Follow

 1 FAILED TEST

```
It seems that the camera does not stay just above the object that followed. I believe the camera stays around ~5 meters/units from the object.
